sen.j: 同心（どうしん）は、江戸幕府の下級役人のひとつ。
sen.e: Doshin refers to one of the low-level officers in the Edo bakufu (government).
sen.cmt: 幕府に（）を補足しました。
sen.e: The term "doshin" refers to one of the low-level officials of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 用語の説明とわかるように引用符とthe termを追加、officersをofficialsに変更、bakufuの説明を用語統一リストに指定されている説明に変更しました。
sen.e: The term "doshin" refers to one of the low-level officials of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 諸奉行・京都所司代・城代・大番頭・書院番頭などの配下で、与力の下にあって庶務・警察などの公務に就いた。
sen.e: They served in a public office to conduct general affairs and police work as a subordinate of police sergeant under the control of magistrates, Kyoto deputies, castle keepers, captains of the great guards, head castle guards and others.
sen.cmt: 文が長く不明確になることを考慮して、役職は（）書きで補足せず、英訳のみにしました。
sen.e: They served in a public office to conduct general affairs and police work as a subordinate of police sergeant under the control of magistrates, Kyoto deputies, castle keepers, captains of the great guards, head castle guards and others.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: They served in a public office to conduct general affairs and police work as a subordinate of police sergeant under the control of magistrates, Kyoto deputies, castle keepers, captains of the great guards, head castle guards and others.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、諸藩においても藩直属の足軽階級の正式名称を同心としているところも少なくない。
sen.e: Also, a lot of domains officially named ashigaru-level soldier (common foot soldier) under the direct control of domain as doshin.
sen.cmt: 足軽階級について（ ）を補足しました。
sen.e: Also, a lot of domains officially named ashigaru-level soldier (common foot soldier) under the direct control of the domain as doshin.
sen.cmt: 冠詞を追加しました。
sen.e: Also, a lot of domains officially named ashigaru-level soldier (common foot soldier) under the direct control of the domain as doshin.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

tit.cmt: 指定の統一用語に訂正しました。

sen.j: 町奉行の下で江戸の司法・行政・警察事務を務めた町方同心、市中見廻りを行なった三廻同心はよく知られている。
sen.e: Machikata doshin, who handled justice, administration and police affairs in Edo under the town magistrate, and Sanmawari doshin, who conducted patrols the town, have been very common.
sen.cmt: ２つの同心について補足して訳さず、原文通りのwho以下の修飾でとどめました。
sen.e: Well-known doshin officials are Machikata-doshin, who handled justice, administration, and police affairs in Edo under the town magistrate, and Sanmawari-doshin, who conducted patrols of the town.
sen.cmt: 主語が長すぎるので文章の構造を変更しました。Patrolsとthe townの間にofを挿入しました。
sen.e: Well-known doshin officials are Machikata-doshin, who handled justice, administration, and police affairs in Edo under the town magistrate, and Sanmawari-doshin, who conducted patrols of the town.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この町方・廻り方同心や火付盗賊改方配下の同心は、捜査の補助や情報源として岡っ引、目明しなどと称する私的な手先を使用することが多かった。
sen.e: The machikata and mawarikata doshins as well as a doshin under an investigation division for arson and organized robbery had a lot of opportunities to use private pawns called okappiki or meakashi as an investigation assistant and information source.
sen.cmt: この文の同心についても説明を補足せず。岡っ引と目明しについても音の訳のみで、説明は文章の訳でとどめました。
sen.e: Machikata and Mawarikata-doshins as well as doshin under the investigation division for arson and organized robbery often used their private pawns called okappiki or meakashi as an investigation assistant and information source.
sen.cmt: 冠詞の修正、「 had a lot of opportunities to use private pawns」を「often used their private pawns」に変更しました。
sen.e: Machikata and Mawarikata-doshins as well as doshin under the investigation division for arson and organized robbery often used their private pawns called okappiki or meakashi as an investigation assistant and information source.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これらのことから推測して、岡っ引や目明しがいわゆる現代の巡査階級の警察官のように言われることがあるが、彼らはあくまで同心の私的使用人にすぎず、正規の町奉行所構成員ではなかった。
sen.e: In the light of the above, okappiki and meakashi were only private servants of a doshin but not proper members of the town magistrate's office although they are sometimes called as if they were patrol police officers today.

In the light of the above, okappiki and meakashi were only private servants of a doshin, not proper members of the town magistrate's office, although they are sometimes regarded as present-day police officers.
sen.cmt: butを削除、「called as if they were patrol police officers today」を「 regarded as present-day police officers」に修正しました。
sen.e: In the light of the above, okappiki and meakashi were only private servants of a doshin, not proper members of the town magistrate's office, although they are sometimes regarded as present-day police officers.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: むしろ、同心が現代の巡査階級の警察官に相当すると言える。
sen.e: Rather, it can be said that doshin corresponds to a modern patrol police officer.
Rather, it can be said that doshin corresponds to a modern patrol police officer.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Rather, it can be said that doshin corresponds to a modern patrol police officer.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 同心は、元々中世後期の日本において「一致団結」を意味する語として使用され、「一味」や「一揆」と同義語であった。
sen.e: Originally, the word doshin was used to mean "be united" during the late mediaeval period in Japan and it was a synonym for "accomplice" or "insurgence".
Originally, the word "doshin" meant "solidarity" during the late mediaeval period in Japan, and it was a synonym of "accomplice" or "insurgence."
sen.cmt: 「was used to mean」をmeantに変更、引用符の追加、前置詞の修正、ピリオドの位置の修正を行いました。
sen.e: Originally, the word "doshin" meant "solidarity" during the late mediaeval period in Japan, and it was a synonym of "accomplice" or "insurgence."
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)に入ると、戦国大名の家臣（下級武士）たちは、主家への平時の奉公や軍役をこなすために相互に団結して事に当たるようになった。
sen.e: In the Warring States period (in Japan), vassals (lower-ranking samurais) of warring lords came to take matters at unity one another in order to perform service in peacetime and military service to a master's house.

In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), vassals (lower-ranked samurai) of a warring lord came to approach matters in unity in order to perform service at ordinary times and do military service for their master's house.
sen.cmt: 「戦国時代」を指定の統一用語に修正、rankingをrankedに修正、warring lordsをa warring lordに修正、takeをapproachに変更、余分な語を削除、前置詞の修正を行いました。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), vassals (lower-ranked samurai) of a warring lord came to approach matters in unity in order to perform service at ordinary times and do military service for their master's house.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのため下級武士を「同心」と呼ぶことが一般的となり、後の江戸幕府も幕臣の役職名として「同心」の称を採用したのである。
sen.e: This made it common to call lower-ranking samurai "doshin", and subsequently, the Edo bakufu decided to use it as a title of shogun's retainer.
This made it common to call lower-ranked samurai "doshin," and subsequently, the Edo bakufu decided to use it as one of official titles of the shogun's retainers.
sen.cmt: rankingをrankedに修正、「a title of shogun's retainer.」を「 one of official titles of the shogun's retainers」に修正、カンマの位置の修正を行いました。
sen.e: This made it common to call lower-ranked samurai "doshin," and subsequently, the Edo bakufu decided to use it as one of official titles of the shogun's retainers.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 江戸幕府成立時、徳川氏直参の足軽を全て同心としたため、忍者を祖先とする伊賀同心、甲賀同心、鉄砲組の百人組、郷士の八王子千人同心等、様々な同心職ができた。
sen.e: Because all the foot soldiers of the Tokugawa's immediate retainers were regarded as doshin when the Edo bakufu was established, various titles of doshin were made: Iga doshin that has ninja ancestry, Koka doshin, one-hundred matchlock infantry unit, Hachioji thousand doshin of country samurai and the like.

Since all the foot soldiers of the Tokugawa clan's immediate retainers became doshin when the Edo bakufu was established, various sorts of doshin were made; for example, Iga doshin and Koka doshin descended from ninja, a one-hundred matchlock infantry unit, Hachioji thousand doshin of country samurai, and so on.
sen.cmt: BecauseをSinceに修正、徳川氏をthe Tokugawa clanに修正、were regraded asをbecameに修正、various titlesをvarious sortsに変更、Koga doshinの位置を修正、that has ninja ancestryをdescended fromに修正、「等」を指定の用語and so onに修正しました。
sen.e: Since all the foot soldiers of the Tokugawa clan's immediate retainers became doshin when the Edo bakufu was established, various sorts of doshin were made; for example, Iga doshin and Koka doshin descended from ninja, a one-hundred matchlock infantry unit, Hachioji thousand doshin of country samurai, and so on.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: このように江戸時代初期から同心となった者は、特に「譜代」と呼ばれ、無役となっても俸禄を受けることができ、子孫にこれを受け継がせることができた。
sen.e: From the early Edo period, those who became a doshin were especially called "fudai" (hereditary vassal), and even if they lost a title, they were still entitled to receive salary and could leave this to their descendants.

Those who became a doshin in the early Edo period were specially called "fudai" (hereditary vassal), and even if they lost their official titles, they were still entitled to receive salary and could leave this to their descendants.
sen.cmt: 冒頭が誤訳なので修正しました。
sen.e: Those who became a doshin in the early Edo period were specially called "fudai" (hereditary vassal), and even if they lost their official titles, they were still entitled to receive salary and could leave this to their descendants.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 幕府の同心は、幕臣であっても旗本ではなく御家人身分であるが、同心筆頭クラスは80石（俵）五人扶持程度の俸禄を受けたので、実質的には100石近い。
sen.e: Doshin of the bakufu were not hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) but bakushin (shogun's retainers), which were in gokenin (shogunal retainers) class, and those who were in the upper rankings of doshin received salary of eighty goku (crop) yields about five times as much as others did, which was almost a hundred goku crop yields, substantially.
sen.cmt: 役職の呼び名の違いと若干の意味の違いを言っている文なので、旗本、幕臣、御家人について（ ）を補足しました。
sen.e: Doshin of the bakufu were not hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) but bakushin (shogun's retainers), which were in the gokenin (shogunal retainers) class, and upper ranked doshin received an eighty-koku (crop) salary and a ration for five persons, which means they substantially had a hundred-koku income approximately.
sen.cmt: 冠詞の修正、80石（俵）五人扶持の意味が誤っていたので修正しました。
sen.e: Doshin of the bakufu were not hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu) but bakushin (shogun's retainers), which were in the gokenin (shogunal retainers) class, and upper ranked doshin received an eighty-koku (crop) salary and a ration for five persons, which means they substantially had a hundred-koku income approximately.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: これは1万石の大名の重臣に匹敵するものである。
sen.e: Their salary was equivalent to that of feudal lord's senior vassals who received ten thousands goku crop yields.
Their salary was equivalent to that of a senior vassal of a feudal lord who had ten thousands- koku crop yields.
sen.cmt: 原文の解釈に誤りがあるので修正しました（1万石あるのは大名であってその重臣ではない）。
sen.e: Their salary was equivalent to that of a senior vassal of a feudal lord who had ten thousands- koku crop yields.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 町奉行配下の与力と同心の多くは、八丁堀 (東京都中央区)に屋敷を拝領し（いわば現代の警察官舎）、しばしば同心の代名詞とされた。
sen.e: Yoriki (police sergeant) under the control of town magistrate and many of doshin were given a residence (which was like modern police quarters) in Hatchobori (Chuo Ward, Tokyo Metropolitan), which was often used as a pronoun for doshin.

Yoriki (police sergeant) under the control of the town magistrate and many of doshin were given their residence (which was like modern police quarters) in Hatchobori (Chuo Ward, Tokyo Prefecture), which was often used as a byword for doshin.
sen.cmt: 冠詞の修正、「東京都」の訳の修正、「代名詞」の訳の修正しました。
sen.e: Yoriki (police sergeant) under the control of the town magistrate and many of doshin were given their residence (which was like modern police quarters) in Hatchobori (Chuo Ward, Tokyo Prefecture), which was often used as a byword for doshin.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ちなみにこの屋敷は、与力が約300坪、同心が約100坪程度の規模であった。
sen.e: In addition, the residence given to yoriki was about 990 sq.m. and doshin about 330 sq.m.
sen.cmt: 1坪を3.3sq.m. で計算してそれのみを書きました。
sen.e: In addition, a residence given to a yoriki was about 990 square meters and a residence given to a doshin was about 330 square meters.
sen.cmt: 冠詞の修正、必要な語句の挿入しました。
sen.e: In addition, a residence given to a yoriki was about 990 square meters and a residence given to a doshin was about 330 square meters.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: いわゆる汚れ仕事として嫌われたために、実質的には世襲ではあったものの、形式的には代替わりの際には新規召抱えの体裁を踏んだ。
sen.e: Because its job was hated as it was unclean in a manner, it was kept save appearances by employing a new person formally upon change of person in charge although it was substantially hereditary.
Since their job was disliked as it was so-called a dirty job, they formally employed a new person when his predecessor left his office although it was substantially hereditary.
sen.cmt: 前半わかりにくいので書き換えました。
sen.e: Since their job was disliked as it was so-called a dirty job, they formally employed a new person when his predecessor left his office although it was substantially hereditary.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 牢屋廻り同心など最下級クラスでは二人扶持程度の俸禄でしかなかったものの、実際は諸大名家や町屋 (商家)からの付け届けなどでかなりの実収入があり、そのため岡っ引や目明しのような私的使用人を雇う余裕もあった。
sen.e: Prison patrol doshin and others in the low rankings of doshin received salary only about twice as much as others did, but in reality they had real handsome income as they received bribes and all from territorial lords and merchants, so they could afford to hire private servants such as okappiki and meakashi (thief-takers).
sen.cmt: 町屋と商屋は英語だとほぼ同じなので、（）書きせず。また、岡っ引と目明しもほぼ同じ意味なので（）書きにまとめて補足しました。
sen.e: Lower ranked doshin such as prison patrol doshin just received a ration for five persons, but in reality they had real handsome income as they received bribes from territorial lords and merchants, so they could afford to hire some private servants such as okappiki and meakashi (thief-takers).
sen.cmt: 冒頭をわかりやすく書き換えました。二人扶持の解釈が誤っているようなので修正しました。
sen.e: Lower ranked doshin such as prison patrol doshin just received a ration for five persons, but in reality they had real handsome income as they received bribes from territorial lords and merchants, so they could afford to hire some private servants such as okappiki and meakashi (thief-takers).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
